dt: {bc}causing a loss of courage or self-confidence {bc}producing feelings of fear or timidity

dt.t: a boss with a very {wi}intimidating{/wi} manner
The Red Army athletes were the most {wi}intimidating{/wi} of competitors.
First jobs are {wi}intimidating{/wi} for everyone, but few people have to cope with the stresses of the workplace at such a tender age as ballet dancers do.

utxt.t: … according to the architect Richard Rogers, [Daniel] Libeskind's work isn't just formally arresting—it is {wi}intimidatingly{/wi} smart.

shortdef: causing a loss of courage or self-confidence : producing feelings of fear or timidity

dt: {bc}to compel or deter by or as if by threats

pt: {sc}intimidate{/sc} {sc}cow{/sc} {sc}bulldoze{/sc} {sc}bully{/sc} {sc}browbeat{/sc} mean to frighten into submission. {sc}intimidate{/sc} implies inducing fear or a sense of inferiority into another.

pt.t: {it}intimidated{/it} by so many other bright freshmen

pt: {sc}cow{/sc} implies reduction to a state where the spirit is broken or all courage is lost.

pt.t: not at all {it}cowed{/it} by the odds against making it in show business

pt: {sc}bulldoze{/sc} implies an intimidating or an overcoming of resistance usually by urgings, demands, or threats.

pt.t: {it}bulldozed{/it} the city council into approving the plan

pt: {sc}bully{/sc} implies intimidation through threats, insults, or aggressive behavior.

pt.t: {it}bullied{/it} into giving up their lunch money

pt: {sc}browbeat{/sc} implies a cowing through arrogant, scornful, or contemptuous treatment.

et: Medieval Latin {it}intimidatus{/it}, past participle of {it}intimidare{/it}, from Latin {it}in-{/it} + {it}timidus{/it} timid
shortdef: to make timid or fearful : frighten; especially : to compel or deter by or as if by threats
